questions.text: Which receptor helps in improvement of insulin resistance in Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus with regular exercise and physical activity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GLUT4

 

GLUT4 is a glucose transporter found primarily in adipose tissues and striated muscles (skeletal and cardiac). It is insulin-dependent, meaning its activity increases in response to insulin. During exercise, the translocation of GLUT4 to the cell membrane is stimulated, enhancing glucose uptake into cells even in the absence of insulin. This mechanism is crucial in improving insulin sensitivity and combating insulin resistance, particularly in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM2). Regular physical activity enhances this effect, leading to better glucose control and reduction of hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT1: This glucose transporter is found in many tissues, including the brain, and is responsible for basal glucose uptake. It is not significantly influenced by insulin and does not play a direct role in improving insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Option C. GLUT2: GLUT2 is primarily found in the liver, pancreas, kidneys, and intestines. It functions in glucose sensing and plays a role in glucose homeostasis but is not directly involved in the insulin-dependent improvement of glucose uptake seen in DM2.

 

Option D. GLUT3: GLUT3 is a high-affinity glucose transporter found predominantly in neurons. It ensures a constant supply of glucose to the brain, but it is not insulin-dependent and does not have a significant role in the management of insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter that plays a key role in improving insulin resistance with regular exercise and physical activity.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

 

  • Diagnosis based on the given image: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (PES)
  • PES is an age-related degenerative disorder, commonly seen in women.
  • Characterized by deposition of an amorphous grey dandruff-like material on:
    • Pupillary border
    • Anterior lens surface
    • Posterior surface of iris
    • Zonules
    • Ciliary processes
  • Trabecular blockage by exfoliative material can lead to:
    • Secondary open-angle glaucoma
    • Rarely, angle-closure glaucoma
  • Other ocular symptoms may include:
    • Iris sphincter atrophy
    • Anisocoria
    • Heterochromia
  • Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.

  • Common intraocular foreign bodies:
    • Glass particles or metal chips.
  • Sites of lodgement: 
    • The anterior chamber
    • Lens
    • Posterior chamber
    • Vitreous humour
  • Consequences of lodgement: 
    • Cataract formation
    • Vitreous liquefaction
    • Retinal haemorrhages
    • Tears
    • Organic foreign bodies can cause infection.
    • Iron foreign bodies can cause siderosis.
    • Copper ones can result in chalcosis.
  • An entry wound can be identified with topical fluorescein.
  • MRI is contraindicated in metallic intraocular foreign bodies.

 

Option C.

 

Ocular trauma can be of 2 types:

  1. Closed-globe injury: can vary from simple corneal abrasions to widespread intraocular damage. A corneal abrasion highlighted with fluorescein staining is shown below.
  2. Open-globe injury: includes globe rupture or laceration.

 

 

Option D. Vossius ring is used to describe a ring-shaped pigment dispersal observed on the anterior surface of the lens due to the deposition of brown amorphous pigment granules. It is close to the constricted pupil in diameter. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, creating an impression of the iris on the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of amorphous grey dandruff-like material on various parts of the eye, leading to potential complications like secondary open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enhance fibrin degradation

 

Tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) converts plasminogen to plasmin that breaks the thrombus, which results in fibrinolysis of formed thrombus (thrombolysis).

 

Drugs in this class include:

 

S – Streptokinase

 

U – Urokinase

 

R – Reteplase

 

A – Alteplase

 

T – Tenecteplase

 

Indication → Pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability

         Acute ischemic stroke

         Acute MI

 

Overdose of thrombolytics

 

→ Leads to bleeding

 

→ Antidotes: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid [EACA]

                      Tranexamic Acid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibit extrinsic pathway: This is not the mechanism of tPA. The extrinsic pathway involves the activation of clotting factors by tissue factor and is more related to clot formation rather than breakdown.

 

Option B. Inhibits platelet aggregation: This is not the mechanism of tPA. Platelet aggregation is inhibited by drugs like aspirin and clopidogrel, not by tPA.

 

Option D. Inhibit clot formation: This is not the mechanism of tPA. Inhibition of clot formation is achieved by anticoagulants like heparin and warfarin, whereas tPA is involved in clot breakdown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) enhances fibrin degradation by converting plasminogen to plasmin, leading to the dissolution of blood clots.

questions.text: Modified shock index is calculated using? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. HR/MAP

 

Modified shock index = HR/MAP

 

A shock index >0.9 is indicative of higher mortality.

 

HR: Heart rate

 

MAP: Mean arterial pressure

 

SBP: Systolic blood pressure

 

DBP: Diastolic blood pressure

 

# Commonly confused:

 

Formula for shock index= Heart rate/ systolic blood pressure

 

Educational Objective :

 

Modified shock index = HR/MAP

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Median

 

  • The uvula vesicae is formed by the prostate's median lobe.
  • The uvula vesicae is a slight elevation on the trigone immediately posterior to the urethral orifice caused by the median lobe of the prostate.
  • In benign prostatic hypertrophy, it is frequently enlarged.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior: The anterior lobe of the prostate, also referred to as the anterior fibromuscular stroma, is found at the front of the prostate, facing the pubic symphysis. Contrary to the other sections of the prostate, this area is primarily made up of fibromuscular tissue and contains fewer glandular elements. It doesn't commonly give rise to clinical conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer.

 

Option B. Posterior: The posterior lobe is located at the back of the prostate, facing the rectum. This part of the prostate is significant clinically because it's the most common site for the development of prostate cancer. During a digital rectal exam, the physician can palpate this lobe, and any firm or irregular nodules felt here could suggest malignancy.

 

Option D. Lateral: The lateral lobes are the large bilateral portions of the prostate on either side of the urethra. These are the most voluminous parts of the prostate and are typically the primary sites involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition in older men where the prostate enlarges and can cause urinary obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle lobe or median lobe of the prostate is situated between the ejaculatory ducts and the urethra. When the median lobe enlarges due to conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), it can project into the bladder, forming a structure called the "uvula vesicae." It is also known as Lietaud’s uvula. This growth can cause urinary symptoms by obstructing the bladder neck.

questions.text: A patient present at 10 weeks pregnancy. She asks for medical method of abortion. What will you advise her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mifepristone and misoprostol

 

The Ans. is Mifepristone and misoprostol. Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) using mifepristone and misoprostol is recommended for up to 12 weeks of gestation as per the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines.

 

 While the Government of India allows medical abortion up to 9 weeks, the WHO supports the use of this regimen until 12 weeks, though the likelihood of failure increases slightly as the gestational age advances. Mifepristone is an anti-progestin that primes the uterus, and misoprostol, a prostaglandin, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy. This combination is effective and widely used in the first trimester and can also be employed in the second trimester with adjustments in misoprostol dosing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperosmolar saline: This is an outdated method and primarily used in the second trimester. It is not recommended for first-trimester abortions due to associated risks and inefficacy compared to current medical regimens.

 

Option C. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is primarily used to induce labor in the second or third trimester. It is not effective or commonly used for first-trimester medical abortions due to its different mechanism of action and limited efficacy in early gestation.

 

Option D. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a prostaglandin used primarily for cervical ripening and labor induction in the third trimester. It is not suitable for first-trimester medical abortion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a medical abortion at 10 weeks, the recommended regimen is mifepristone followed by misoprostol, as it is effective and safe up to 12 weeks of gestation according to WHO guidelines.

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

 

The most appropriate next step for a child with a VP shunt who presents with symptoms suspicious for meningitis is to obtain blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples from the shunt tap and/or lumbar puncture. It is important to diagnose and treat meningitis quickly in patients with VP shunts, as untreated meningitis can cause shunt malfunction and other complications.

 

The diagnosis of meningitis in a child with a VP shunt requires obtaining blood cultures and CSF samples. Blood cultures are needed to identify the causative organism, while CSF samples are used to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the infection. CSF can be obtained either through a shunt tap or a lumbar puncture, depending on the child's clinical status and the availability of the appropriate resources.

 

VP shunt fluid is usually obtained from a reservoir that is easily accessible subcutaneously. After sterile preparation, the reservoir should be punctured with a 25-gauge needle. The risk of introducing infection is also low (4.1%).

 

 

Ventriculoperitoneal shunt:

 

 

A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CS) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

 

Complications of the shunting procedure include the following:

 

  • Infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, usually from Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • Intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Shunt over drainage (slit ventricles)
  • Shunt nephritis
  • Shunt disconnection
  • Shunt obstruction
  • Inguinal hernia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch: as the patient is showing features of complication, wait and watch will not be the appropriate answer.

 

Option B. Check shunt patency by nuclear study: we should check the patency of the shunt but as the patient is showing signs of meningitis we should do a CSF analysis by shunt tap.

 

Option C. Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture: the main source of infection is from the shunt, so taking CSF sample from there is best.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best step for a child with a VP shunt showing signs of meningitis is to perform a blood culture and obtain a CSF sample from the shunt tap.

choices.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives at the emergency department, reporting upper abdominal pain that started after consuming a large meal. During the physical examination, there's notable tenderness in the upper abdominal region. Findings from a chest X-ray show an enlargement of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave's syndrome. It occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis/cricopharynx, leading to a massive rise in esophageal pressure and subsequent perforation. This typically happens on the left lower wall of the esophagus.

 

Clinical Features of Spontaneous Perforation of the Esophagus (Boerhaave's Syndrome):

 

  1. Chest Pain: Sudden and severe pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen, often exacerbated by swallowing.
  2. Vomiting: Severe vomiting that precedes the onset of pain, leading to esophageal rupture.
  3. Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath: Due to leakage of air and fluids into the chest cavity, causing pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
  4. Subcutaneous Emphysema: Air leaks from the esophagus into the chest wall, causing a characteristic crackling sensation when the skin is palpated.
  5. Shock: Severe cases may lead to shock due to sepsis or hypovolemia.
  6. Hamman's Sign: A crunching or rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium or left lateral chest wall on auscultation, caused by heartbeats displacing air-filled tissues.
  7. Abdominal Pain and Tenderness: Especially if the perforation is near the lower part of the esophagus.
  8. Fever: A response to inflammation and infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforation of peptic ulcer: This usually presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis. The diagnosis would typically show free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray, not mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Foreign body in esophagus: This condition may cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and localized pain but is less likely to present with mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum unless it leads to perforation.

 

Option D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung: This condition can cause sudden chest pain and pneumothorax but does not typically present with pneumomediastinum and is not related to eating or upper abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus (Boerhaave's syndrome) is characterized by severe chest pain, vomiting, dyspnea, subcutaneous emphysema, and pneumomediastinum, often following severe vomiting. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these symptoms, especially with radiographic evidence of mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

 

Explanation

 

The above clinical scenario depicts transection of the spinal cord in the lateral aspect of the dorsal column would affect the fasciculus cuneatus. This lesion would result in absence of ipsilateral proprioception of the arm.

 

 

The fibers in the dorsal column are arranged in such a manner that the sacral segments are positioned most medially and those from the cervical segments are positioned most laterally.

 

These are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus gracilis - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb
  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus cuneatus - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral upper limb.

 

Fasciculus Gracilis and Cuneatus functions:

 

  1. Fine touch
  2. Tactile localization
  3. Tactile discrimination
  4. Vibration

 

This patient with an injury to the lateral part of the cervical cord's dorsal column tract will have damaged fasciculus cuneatus. This would result in loss of touch, vibration, and proprioception in the arm of the same side of the lesion.

 

function below the level of injury. The clue to solving this question is that the question mentions that the damage is to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception: This would be seen if the fasciculus gracilis was affected, which is responsible for carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb.

 

Option B. Absence of fine motor movement of fingers: This would be a result of damage to the corticospinal tract, which carries motor information.

 

Option D. Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception: Proprioception is carried by the dorsal column pathway, and it is affected ipsilaterally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract in the cervical spine region results in the loss of ipsilateral arm proprioception due to the involvement of the fasciculus cuneatus. This emphasizes the importance of the dorsal column in carrying proprioceptive and fine tactile information from the upper limbs.

 

Additional Information

 

Brown Sequard Syndrome (Hemi-sectioning of spinal cord)

 

  • I/L loss of Fine touch
  • C/L loss of Pain & Temperature
  • I/L loss of Proprioception
  • I/L motor paralysis

choices.text: Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, no salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, minor salivary glands

questions.text: During a histological examination of the oral cavity, which combination of features is typically seen in the hard palate mucosa? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands

 

Hard palate is composed of a dense layer of connective tissue covered by a specialized oral mucosa. It is composed of keratinized epithelium, a submucosal layer for support, and contains minor salivary glands. These structures contribute to the function of the hard palate in speech, mastication (chewing), and the initial digestion of food in the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hard palate is composed of keratinized epithelium to withstand mechanical stress, a submucosa that provides structural support, and contains minor salivary glands, which are essential for the lubrication and initial digestion of food. This structural composition is crucial for its function in the oral cavity.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with distant visual acuity of 6/18, which improved on pin-hole testing. He gives history of not needing glasses for near vision now. On ocular examination findings as shown in image were seen. Patient has which of the following refractory error. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Index Myopia

 

Given the patient's age and the description of the symptoms, the most likely refractive error in this case is Index Myopia. This occurs when nuclear sclerosis starts in the crystalline lens, resulting in change in the density and hence the refractive index of the lens. This causes light rays to focus in front of the retina, leading to blurred distant vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axial Myopia: Axial myopia is a common form of myopia and is usually a stable condition that doesn't suddenly appear in old age.

 

Option B. Curvatural Myopia: This form of myopia is due to an increased curvature of the cornea or lens, which makes the eye's focusing power too strong. This also results in the focal point being in front of the retina, causing distant objects to be blurred. Like axial myopia, curvatural myopia is generally present from a younger age and does not develop suddenly in seniors.

 

Option C. Positional Myopia: This type of myopia can occur due to the displacement of the lens within the eye, which can sometimes happen with a subluxated lens. Positional myopia is not a common form of myopia and would not typically be associated with the symptom of improved near vision without the need for glasses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phenomenon of "second sight" in older adults is often associated with the development of nuclear sclerotic cataracts, which can cause a change in the refractive index of the lens, leading to index myopia. An important clinical sign is improvement in near vision in a previously hypermetropic (or presbyopic) individual, along with a decrease in distance vision that improves with pinhole testing. It's essential to recognize these signs and symptoms for the correct diagnosis and management of cataracts.

choices.text: Thrombocytopenia-absent radius syndrome

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

WISKOTT-ALDRICH SYNDROME (WAS)

 

  • It is a complex, recessive, X-linked disease

 

Mutations:

 

  • WASP gene (affect not only T lymphocytes but also the other lymphocyte subsets, dendritic cells, and platelets).

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • WASP regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus plays an important role in many lymphocyte functions, including cell adhesion and migration and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting cell and target cells.

 

Clinical manifestations:

 

  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Eczema
  • Bleeding caused by thrombocytopenia
  • Null mutations predispose affected individuals to invasive and bronchopulmonary infections, viral infections, severe eczema, and autoimmune manifestations.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Reduced-sized platelets on a blood smear.
  • Intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASP) expression in blood cells.

 

Treatment:

 

  • According to the severity of disease expression.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics, immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation, and careful topical treatment of eczema.
  • Although splenectomy improves platelet count in a majority of cases, this intervention is associated with a significant risk of infection (both before and after HSCT).
  • Allogeneic HSCT is curative, with fairly good results overall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B:  Chediak higashi occurs due to LyST (Lysosomal transfer protein) defect characterized by recurrent infections, oculo-cutaneous albinism

 

Option C: TAR is associated with thrombocytopenia at birth

 

Option D:  Hermansky-Pudlak occurs due to deficiency of dense granules in platelets characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, ILD, Granulomatous colitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is distinguished by its symptom triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections, directly related to mutations in the WASP gene affecting cellular function and immune response. Understanding these features is critical in diagnosing the syndrome and managing its complex clinical manifestations effectively.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Immunodeficiencies/Chapter 351,374

questions.text: The persistence of ADHD in childhood increases the risk of development of which of the following in adolescence? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conduct disorder

 

Children with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) are at an increased risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence. ADHD is characterized by impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention, which can lead to difficulty in following rules, controlling behavior, and maintaining social norms. When these symptoms persist into adolescence, they can manifest as more serious behavioral problems, such as conduct disorder, characterized by aggressive, antisocial, or defiant behaviors.

 

Conduct disorder is a common progression from ADHD because the underlying impulsivity and lack of self-control associated with ADHD often worsen over time, particularly when untreated. This progression underscores the importance of early intervention in managing ADHD symptoms.

 

Note - Children with ADHD are at risk of developing depression, antisocial personality disorder, substance use disorder, and conduct disorder as adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective mutism: This disorder involves a consistent failure to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in other situations, and it is more associated with anxiety disorders rather than ADHD.

 

Option C. Binge eating disorder: This condition involves recurrent episodes of eating large quantities of food, often quickly and to the point of discomfort. It is associated more with emotional regulation issues rather than impulsivity or behavioral problems typical of ADHD.

 

Option D. Separation anxiety disorder: This disorder is characterized by excessive fear or anxiety about separation from attachment figures. It is more commonly associated with anxiety disorders and does not have a direct link to ADHD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The persistence of ADHD in childhood significantly increases the risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence, highlighting the need for early and effective management of ADHD symptoms.

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

 

Explanation

 

In the above scenario, the patient has developed paresis (partial paralysis) but the pain sensation is intact (no numbness) suggests A fibers involvement as they carry motor, touch, and pressure sensations are most sensitive to pressure changes/compression.

 

A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception (the sense of one's body position). C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated and transmit slower pain signals. While both types of fibers can be affected by pressure, A fibers are more vulnerable to damage from sustained pressure than C fibers, which are more resistant to compression.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers. - Incorrect. C fibers are unmyelinated and relatively more resistant to pressure compared to myelinated A fibers.

 

Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers. - Not relevant to the scenario, as the issue is related to mechanical pressure, not oxygen deprivation.

 

Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers. - Also not relevant to the given scenario, focusing on hypoxia instead of the impact of mechanical pressure or compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative susceptibility -

questions.text: Which parameters would you utilize to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programmer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Annual Blood Examination Rate

 

Annual blood examination rate (ABER): (Index of operational efficiency)

 

 

 

ABER is a critical parameter used to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Program. It reflects the proportion of the population that is being tested for malaria and helps determine the operational efficiency of the surveillance system. High ABER indicates effective surveillance and control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual parasitic incidence (API): Sophisticated measure of malaria incidence in a community

 

 

Option C. Slide positivity rate (SPR):

 

 

Option D. Slide falciparum rate: specifically measures the proportion of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum, the most severe form of malaria. It indicates the burden of P. falciparum in the population.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In an isolated mitochondria, in a medium containing Succinate, Fumarate, ADP and Pi, ATPs were produced. Later a compound was added, and oxidative phosphorylation was decreased. What’s that compound? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oligomycin

 

  • Oligomycin is an antibiotic that inhibits ATP synthase, a key enzyme complex in oxidative phosphorylation. It blocks the flow of protons (H+) through ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis. As a result, adding oligomycin would indeed decrease oxidative phosphorylation, leading to a reduction in ATP production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP): 2,4-dinitrophenol is a chemical uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation. It disrupts the proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane, making it leaky to protons. This uncoupling reduces the efficiency of ATP production but doesn't directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option C. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It blocks the transfer of electrons from ubiquinone to cytochrome c, disrupting the electron flow in the chain.

 

Option D. Rotenone: Rotenone is an inhibitor of complex I in the electron transport chain. It prevents the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone, disrupting electron flow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligomycin specifically targets ATP synthase and inhibits ATP synthesis in oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, the compound that was added to the isolated mitochondria, leading to a decrease in oxidative phosphorylation

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 123

questions.text: Which of the following elicits maximum pain on injection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propofol

 

  • Propofol is notorious for causing pain upon injection.
  • The pain can be severe and is often described as a burning sensation.
  • Various techniques and adjuncts, like mixing with lidocaine or injecting into larger veins, have been recommended to minimize the pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketamine: While ketamine can sometimes cause a burning sensation upon injection, it's not typically described as the most painful among anesthetic agents. However, when not combined with other medications, it can cause some discomfort upon injection.

 

Option C. Etomidate: Etomidate can cause pain on injection, but the pain is generally less severe compared to propofol.

 

Option D. Thiopentone: Thiopentone can cause some pain upon injection, but it's generally less painful than propofol. However, it can cause tissue necrosis if it is inadvertently injected outside of the vein (extravasation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is known to cause maximum pain on injection, often described as a severe burning sensation.

choices.text: Phosphatidyl serine

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine

 

Explanation

 

  • Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of dipalmitoyl-phosphatidyl-choline (DPPC) /dipalmitoyl lecithin. It is the major pulmonary surfactant (surfactant is a surface-active agent, secreted by type II alveolar epithelial cells) It is a complex mixture of several phospholipids, proteins, and ions.
  • The most important components are the phospholipid dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine, surfactant apoproteins, and calcium ions.
  • The surfactant decreases the surface tension in the alveoli 2- to 10-fold, which normally plays a major role in preventing alveolar collapse.
  • However, in a number of conditions, such as in hyaline membrane disease (also called respiratory distress syndrome), which often occurs in newborn premature babies, the quantity of surfactant secreted by the alveoli is so greatly depressed that the surface tension of the alveolar fluid becomes several times normal. This causes a serious tendency for the lungs of these babies to collapse or to become filled with fluid.
  • Clinical relevance - Test to assess fetal lung maturity is L/S ratio –lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio. A ratio of ≥ 2 is considered normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphatidyl serine: Incorrect. While phosphatidyl serine is a component of cell membranes and plays roles in signaling, it is not a major component of pulmonary surfactant and is not specifically linked to respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option C. Phosphatidylethanolamine: Incorrect. Similar to phosphatidyl serine, phosphatidylethanolamine is a component of cell membranes and is involved in cellular processes but does not play a direct role in reducing alveolar surface tension or preventing respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option D. Phosphatidylinositol: Incorrect. Phosphatidylinositol is involved in cellular signaling pathways and membrane structure but is not a significant component of pulmonary surfactant related to respiratory function or the pathology of respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is crucial for reducing surface tension in the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and is the primary component deficient in respiratory distress syndrome, particularly in premature infants. This deficiency underscores the importance of surfactant therapy in the management of this condition.

choices.text: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases. This type of cancer originates from the glandular cells lining the rectum. Therefore, stating that adenocarcinoma is a rare variant is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients: This statement is true. Hartmann's operation is a surgical procedure often performed in elderly or debilitated patients with rectal carcinoma. The operation involves resection of the diseased segment of the colon, closure of the remaining rectal stump (forming a "Hartmann's pouch"), and creation of an end colostomy with the proximal colon. It is a suitable option for patients who may not tolerate a more extensive surgical procedure.

 

Option C. Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur: This statement is true. Patients with rectal carcinoma commonly experience symptoms such as diarrhea and tenesmus (a sensation of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements). These symptoms can occur at any time of the day, including early morning, due to the irritation and obstruction caused by the tumor.

 

Option D. Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging: This statement is true. According to the modified Duke's staging system for colorectal cancer, stage A refers to cancer that is confined to the mucosa of the rectum. This early stage indicates that the tumor has not yet penetrated deeper layers or spread beyond the rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases, making it incorrect to describe it as a rare variant.

questions.text: A patient came with complains of hair loss. His wife mentions that she has noticed some behavioral changes. The doctor notices that there is a loss of eyebrows on the lateral side. He then comes to a conclusion by examining the nails. What is the type of poisoning in this case? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thallium

 

  • Alopecia is the most characteristic feature of Thallium, especially loss of eyebrows on lateral side
  • Both thallium and arsenic have many similar features (both have Mees lines, peripheral neuropathies, GI symptoms, skin symptoms etc.) But the key differentiating feature is thallium is associated more with alopecia, whereas, arsenic more with GI symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning presents with Mees' lines, peripheral neuropathies, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Alopecia can occur, but it is more closely associated with gastrointestinal symptoms than with hair loss.

 

Option C. Mercury: Mercury poisoning can cause alopecia, but it is also associated with tremors, irritability, and renal issues.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning is associated with gastrointestinal symptoms and neurological issues such as abdominal pain and peripheral neuropathy but not typically with alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alopecia is seen in Thallium, arsenic and mercury poisoning
  • Mees lines in nails are seen in Thallium and Arsenic poisoning

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. 24-hour urine volume was measured and recorded to be 7 liters. The urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. ADH assay was performed and the recorded values were reported as 0.8 pg/mL. An MRI of the brain was performed and T1 weighted indicated the absence of the bright spot. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pituitary DI

 

The patient's symptoms of frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis combined with a large urine output (7 liters) and low urine osmolarity (260 mOsm/L) suggest a deficiency in ADH effect. The low ADH level (0.8 pg/mL) and the absence of the bright spot on T1 weighted MRI (indicative of a pituitary abnormality) further support the diagnosis of Pituitary Diabetes Insipidus (DI). In Pituitary DI, ADH (vasopressin) is not adequately produced by the hypothalamus or released from the posterior pituitary, which leads to reduced water reabsorption in the kidney and subsequent polyuria.

 

Approach to Polyuria:

 

  • Water vs solute diuresis: (first thing to know)
  • Water diuresis: DI, Primary polydipsia
  • Solute diuresis:
    • Glycosuria (Hyperglycemia, SGLT2 inhibitor use)
    • Iatrogenic hyper-osmolar agents (Hypertonic saline, Mannitol, Urea - from high-protein tube feeding, Radiocontrast agents)
    • Salt wasting (e.g., Medullary cystic disease, Diuretics, CSWS, Obstructive uropathy -especially if B/L, resolving ATN)
  • Before giving desmopressin → S. Na+ should be 145(or) P. Osm should be > 295.
  • If this cannot be achieved (usually due to severe thirst) during water deprivation - Alternative for water deprivation is Hypertonic saline infusion to achieve S. Na > 145 or P. Osm > 295 - then desmopressin test can be performed.
  • Hypertonic saline (to ↑P. Osm) + Plasma AVP measurement in response to ↑ P. Osm due to hypertonic saline. Plasma AVP is unstable and needs stringent storage techniques. Based on AVP levels- can diagnose pituitary vs nephrogenic vs primary polydipsia. Diagnostic accuracy is questionable.

 

 

**Plasma Co-Peptin (analogues to C-peptide of insulin) can be used for central vs nephrogenic DI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephrogenic DI: Incorrect because it typically involves normal or high levels of ADH, but the kidneys do not respond to it. The patient's ADH is low, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Primary polydipsia: This is associated with excessive fluid intake leading to large volumes of dilute urine but generally will not affect ADH levels significantly, and the brain MRI would typically be normal.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: This causes an osmotic diuresis due to the mannitol not being reabsorbed in the renal tubules. There is no evidence of mannitol administration in the patient's history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MMS algorithm for finding out the cause:

questions.text: Which of the following muscles functions as a tensor of the vocal cords? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cricothyroid

 

Cricothyroid is a tensor of vocal cord.

 

The cricothyroid muscle is primarily responsible for lengthening and tensing the vocal cords. When this muscle contracts, it pulls the thyroid cartilage forward and down towards the cricoid cartilage, which results in elongation and tensioning of the vocal cords. This action increases the pitch of the voice. Because of its role in tensioning the vocal cords, the cricothyroid is sometimes referred to as a tensor of the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral cricoarytenoid: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscles are responsible for adducting the vocal cords. When these muscles contract, they rotate the arytenoid cartilages medially, which causes the vocal cords to come together. This action is crucial for phonation (production of sound), as the vocal cords must be close together to vibrate against each other. However, the lateral cricoarytenoids do not play a direct role in the tensioning or relaxation of the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Thyroarytenoids: The thyroarytenoids are the primary muscles within the vocal cords themselves. They have two parts: the thyrovocalis (medial) and the thyromuscularis (lateral). The thyrovocalis is involved in the shortening and tensioning of the vocal cords, leading to a decrease in pitch. In contrast, the thyromuscularis aids in relaxing and thickening the cords, which lowers the pitch. Together, they play a critical role in controlling pitch and the quality of the voice.

 

Option D. Posterior cricoarytenoids: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the primary muscles responsible for abducting or opening the vocal cords. They rotate the arytenoid cartilages laterally, which pulls the vocal cords apart. This action is vital for breathing, as the vocal cords must be open for air to flow into the lungs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism. What would be the appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Spherical equivalent spectacles

 

The appropriate management for myopic astigmatism in a 15-year-old girl (<18 years) would be spherical equivalent spectacles.

 

The three components of prescription in astigmatism are:

 

  • Power of the spherical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre sphere (DS)
  • Power of the cylindrical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre cylinder (DC)
  • Axis or orientation of the cylinder.

 

The cylindrical power and axis are correcting the astigmatic part of the refractive error. If an astigmatic eye were to be corrected with a spherical lens alone, the result would be a blur circle on the retina, called the circle of least confusion.

 

The spherical lens power places the circle of least confusion on the retina and is called the spherical equivalent. It is defined as the spherical power whose focal point coincides with the circle of least confusion, where one would see minimal blurring in their vision.
 

 

For example, for spherical power is +2 and cylindrical power is +3,

Spherical equivalent = +2.00 +(+3.00 /2) = +3.50.

 

Spherical equivalent spectacles are given if one has to give less cylinder power than was measured.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. and C - LASIK and Femto LASIK: should be done in patients above 18 years of age.

 

Option D. Implantable Collamer lens: is indicated for patients 21-45 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical interventions like LASIK and Femto LASIK are not recommended for individuals under 18 years of age.

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prozone phenomenon

 

The initial negative test is explained by the prozone phenomenon. The standard agglutination test is a tube agglutination test that mainly identifies IgM antibodies. It is used in establishing a diagnosis of acute brucellosis.

 

Prozone phenomenon refers to the failure of a visible precipitation reaction due to inhibition of lattice formation by the presence of excessive antibodies. This gives rise to a false-negative test. This excess in antibodies can be overcome by diluting the serum sample, leading to an increase in LATTICE FORMATION where the antigen-antibody interactions are equal, eventually giving rise to a positive result.

 

Lattice hypothesis: The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. The point where the antigen and the antibody are in the same amount , best interaction takes place in this zone called as the zone of equivalence. 

 

  • Prozone phenomenon: Caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation-false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigens and antibodies are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post-zone phenomenon: Due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incomplete antibodies: These are not typically responsible for the phenomenon described. Incomplete antibodies generally do not cause agglutination but can bind antigens.

 

Option B. Complement inactivation: This would not typically result in the observed test pattern and is more relevant in tests involving complement fixation.

 

Option D. Post-zone phenomenon: Occurs when there is an excess of antigen, not antibodies, leading to a lack of visible agglutination due to insufficient cross-linking by antibodies.

 

Educational Objective

 

The prozone phenomenon, responsible for initial false-negative results in serological tests like the standard agglutination test for brucellosis, occurs due to excessive antibodies preventing visible agglutination. This can be corrected by diluting the serum, which highlights the importance of considering antibody concentration in diagnostic testing.

choices.text: Karyotype is 46 XY
Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy
The response of testosterone to hCG is increased
Uterus is usually absent

questions.text: What is true about ovotesticular disorders of sex development? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy

 

  • Ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD) is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue in the same individual.
  • Most affected individuals have a 46, XX chromosomal karyotype, which normally results in female sexual development.
  • In about 10% of patients, testicular tissue in an individual with a 46, XX karyotype is present as a result of a translocation of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome to the X chromosome or another chromosome.
  • An abnormal vagina and underdeveloped uterus are usually present.
  • The testes are usually undescended, and the penis may present with hypospadias.
  • Upon reaching puberty, breast development, feminization, and menstruation may occur.
  • Most affected individuals are infertile, but ovulation or spermatogenesis is possible.
  • The response of testosterone to hCG is normal or reduced.
  • A defect in R-spondin1 protein encoded by the RSPO1 gene is described in 46, XX ovotesticular DSD.
  • An ovotestis is present in approximately 2/3 of affected individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovotesticular disorder of sex development is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues, typically with a 46, XX karyotype and possible SRY gene translocation, and can present with ovotestis seen on gonadal biopsy.

choices.text: Ito cells
Endothelial cells

questions.text: Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ito cells

 

Explanation

 

  • Ito cells are the cells that store vitamin A in the liver. These cells, also known as hepatic stellate cells, are located in the space of Disse, which is between the hepatocytes and the endothelial cells in the liver.
  • Ito cells play a role in liver function and pathology, and are involved in the regulation of extracellular matrix synthesis and degradation, as well as in the response to liver injury. They are also responsible for the storage and release of vitamin A in the liver.
  • Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specialized macrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatocytes: Incorrect, while hepatocytes are the main functional cells of the liver and perform numerous metabolic, synthetic, and detoxifying functions, they are not the primary storage sites for vitamin A.

 

Option C. Endothelial cells: Incorrect, these cells line the blood vessels of the liver and are involved in filtration and blood flow regulation within the organ, not in vitamin storage.

 

Option D. Kupffer cells: Incorrect, Kupffer cells are the liver's resident macrophages, involved in immune responses and the breakdown of red blood cells, not in storing vitamins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ito cells (hepatic stellate cells) are the primary storage sites for vitamin A in the liver. Their role extends beyond vitamin storage to include critical functions in the regulation of the extracellular matrix and the liver's response to injury.

choices.text: Factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factors II, VII, IX, and X

 

Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X are zymogens of serine proteases that contain glutamic acid residues. These residues undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation via gamma-glutamyl carboxylase to form gamma-carboxy glutamic acid residues. This enables them to bind calcium ions (Ca2+), which is necessary for their activation and subsequent blood clot formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factors II, VIII, IX, X: Factor VIII is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation but does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option C. Factors II, VII, IX, XI: Factor XI is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is activated by thrombin and does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option D. Factors II, VIII, X, XI: Neither Factor VIII nor Factor XI are zymogens that require gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. They do not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zymogens are the proprotein form of enzymes (proenzymes) that require proteolytic activation to carry out their function.

 

Inactive form of vitamin K acts as a cofactor in the post-synthetic modification of these zymogens and their activation. This inactive form of vitamin K is recycled back from its oxidized form by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which can be inhibited by warfarin or liver failure.

choices.text: 4 years
7 years
9 years

questions.text: A child who is a victim under POCSO act is brought to the department of forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 13 years

 

The X-ray image shows:

 

  • All carpal bones are developed. This implies age is > 10 years. Pisiform is the last bone to appear which is visible and can be easily identified as marked below:

 

 

  • Base of the first metacarpal has not united with the shaft (It fuses at 15-17 years age). This implies age is < 17 years.

 

Hence, age is 10-17 years. So, the best answer here is 13 years.

 

Educational Objective

 

Age of appearance of carpal bones is given below:

questions.text: Identify the structure given in the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

The structure given in the image is the incus.

 

The malleus has head, neck, handle (manubrium), a lateral and an anterior process. Head and neck of malleus lie in the attic. Manubrium is embedded in the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane. The lateral process forms a knob-like projection on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane and gives attachment to the anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

 

The incus has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic, and a long process which hangs vertically and attaches to the head of stapes.

 

The stapes has a head, neck, anterior and posterior crura, and a footplate. The footplate is held in the oval window by annular ligament.


Other Options:

 

Option A. The malleus is the largest ossicle and is shaped like a mallet. The parts of the malleus are the head, neck, handle (manubrium), and anterior and lateral processes. The head and neck lie in the attic.

 

The tympanic membrane is connected to the handle of the malleus.

 

Option C. The stapes has a head, neck, footplate, and anterior and posterior crura. The annular ligament holds the footplate of stapes in the oval window.

 

 

The joints between the ear ossicles are synovial joints. A saddle-shaped joint is present between the incus and malleus. Incus and stapes articulate via a ball and socket joint.

 

Options D. Vomer A facial bone forming part of the nasal septum, unrelated to the middle ear.

Educational Objective:

 

The incus is one of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. It plays a critical role in hearing by transmitting sound vibrations from the malleus to the stapes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 9

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Since the tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

 

 

Referred causes of otalgia. Pain is referred via CN V (teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, anterior two-thirds of tongue), C2,3 (cervical spine), CN IX (tonsil, base of tongue, elongated styloid process) and CN X (vallecula, pyriform fossa or larynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial nerve - This nerve primarily deals with facial expressions and some sensory functions of the face, not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis to the ear.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve - While it is a significant sensory nerve for the face, it is more commonly associated with referred pain from the teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via CN V).

 

Option D. Vagus nerve - Involved in sensory functions from the base of the tongue, vallecula, pyriform fossa, and larynx, not directly involved in referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Referred otalgia from tonsillitis is most commonly mediated through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), highlighting the importance of the nerve's role in sensory transmission from the tonsils and tonsillar fossa to the ear.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation, the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phrenicocolic ligament

 

  • The downward movement of the spleen is naturally prevented by the phrenicocolic ligament, which does not attach to the spleen itself but supports its anterior end.
  • This ligament is a horizontal fold of peritoneum that extends from the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm, opposite of the 11th rib in the midaxillary line. The phrenicocolic ligament also limits the upper end of the left paracolic gutter.
  • In cases where the spleen becomes enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament and splenic flexure of the colon restrict its downward displacement. This enlargement typically occurs towards the right iliac fossa, causing the spleen to be directed obliquely.
  • By supporting the anterior end of the spleen, the phrenicocolic ligament plays an important role in preventing its excessive movement and displacement within the abdominal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lienorenal ligament: This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney and contains the tail of the pancreas and vessels that supply the spleen. It helps to hold the spleen in its anatomical position, preventing it from moving medially.

 

Option B. Gastrosplenic ligament: This is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the greater curvature of the stomach to the hilum of the spleen. It contains the short gastric vessels and contributes to the attachment of the spleen to the stomach. It prevents the spleen from moving too far posteriorly.

 

Option D. Lienophrenic ligament: The term "lienophrenic ligament" isn't a standard anatomical term. The spleen does have ligamentous connections with the diaphragm, but these are typically referred to as part of the lienorenal and gastrosplenic ligaments. Therefore, this option might be a misnomer or less commonly used terminology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrenicocolic ligament extends from the left colic (splenic) flexure of the colon to the diaphragm. It's positioned to the left side of the abdomen and is an important anatomical landmark. It acts as a supportive structure, supporting the left colic flexure and acting as a barrier. Importantly, it prevents the downward and medial displacement of the spleen, especially when the spleen enlarges, as in cases of splenomegaly.

 

Splenic ligaments and their attachments:

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and swelling of the face. Intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. There was evidence of vascular invasion. What will be the preferred treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amphotericin B

 

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching and evidence of vascular invasion are characteristic of mucormycosis, a serious fungal infection commonly seen in diabetic patients and other immunocompromised individuals. Amphotericin B is the preferred initial treatment for mucormycosis due to its broad antifungal coverage and effectiveness against Mucorales, the group of fungi responsible for this infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used primarily for Candida and Cryptococcus infections. It is not effective against Mucorales and therefore not suitable for treating mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is another antifungal agent with a broad spectrum of action but has limited use due to its side effects and is not effective against Mucorales, making it inappropriate for mucormycosis treatment.

 

Option D. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin is used for dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea infections) and is not effective against Mucorales. It is not suitable for treating mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Mucormycosis:

 

  • Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that requires prompt and aggressive treatment due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate.
  • The mainstay of treatment is intravenous Amphotericin B, often followed by oral posaconazole or isavuconazole for maintenance therapy.
  • Surgical debridement of infected tissue is frequently necessary.
  • Controlling underlying conditions like diabetes is also crucial in managing mucormycosis.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of staring into space with frequent visual hallucinations. Pathology reveals Lewy bodies in neurons. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Parkinson’s Disease

 

The presence of Lewy bodies, which are aggregates of alpha-synuclein protein, in neurons suggests either Parkinson's disease or Lewy body dementia. Given the patient's symptoms of progressive decline in daily activity, visual hallucinations, and pathology findings, Parkinson's disease is the most likely diagnosis.

 

  • Lewy Bodies: These are characteristic of Parkinson’s disease and Lewy body dementia. They are intraneuronal inclusions primarily composed of alpha-synuclein.
  • Visual Hallucinations: These are more common in Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia compared to other neurodegenerative disorders.
  • Parkinson’s Disease: The diagnosis is supported by the clinical history of visual hallucinations and progressive decline, alongside the pathological finding of Lewy bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prion’s Disease: Typically presents with rapidly progressing dementia and myoclonus. EEG shows characteristic periodic sharp wave complexes, and CSF may show elevated 14.3.3 protein. This does not match the patient's clinical picture.

 

Option C. Huntington’s Disease: An inherited condition characterized by the classic triad of dementia, chorea, and psychiatric manifestations. This condition usually presents earlier in life and has a strong family history component.

 

Option D. Alzheimer’s Disease: Primarily presents with memory loss and later with visual-spatial problems and the "four A’s" (amnesia, agnosia, apraxia, aphasia). Pathologically, it is characterized by beta-amyloid plaques and tau protein tangles, not Lewy bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lewy bodies in neurons and clinical features such as visual hallucinations and progressive decline in activity are indicative of Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found to be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg and is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. The viral load of the patient was 2 x 10^5 IU/mL and ALT is found to be doubled. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tenofovir

 

The patient is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B, as indicated by the positive HBsAg and HBeAg, which are markers of infection and infectivity, respectively. The viral load of 2 x 105 IU/mL and elevated ALT levels suggest active viral replication and liver inflammation.

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This is a marker of infection. Its presence indicates that the person is infectious.

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): This is a marker of infectivity. It indicates that the virus is replicating and the patient is highly infectious.

 

HBV DNA: This is a marker of viral replication. In chronic hepatitis B, a high level of HBV DNA correlates with an increased risk of complications such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

The decision to start treatment in chronic hepatitis B is primarily based on the levels of HBV DNA and ALT. According to guidelines, treatment is indicated if:

 

  1. HBV DNA is more than 2000 IU/mL.
  2. ALT is elevated (more than 2 to 3 times the upper limit of normal).

 

In this patient, both criteria are met.

 

Tenofovir is preferred for its efficacy and lower risk of resistance compared to other options like lamivudine. Tenofovir is also favored over interferon-based therapies due to better durability of response and lower side effect profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lamivudine: This drug is no longer preferred due to a high risk of resistance.

 

Option C. Peg IFN for 52 weeks: Pegylated interferon is not preferred due to less favorable response rates and a higher side effect profile compared to tenofovir.

 

Option D. Combined peg IFN with lamivudine: Combination therapy with pegylated interferon and lamivudine is not recommended due to increased side effects and no significant improvement in efficacy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tenofovir is the preferred treatment for chronic hepatitis B with high viral load and elevated ALT levels due to its efficacy and lower risk of resistance.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

 

The scenario described involves the teacher demonstrating a physical skill (handwashing), which the students then practice and replicate. This type of learning pertains to the acquisition of motor skills and involves physical movement and coordination, making it psychomotor learning.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cognitive: It pertains to mental skills or acquiring knowledge. It involves understanding, reasoning, and thinking processes.

 

Option C. Affective: It relates to feelings, values, attitudes, motivations, and appreciations.

 

Option D. Affective and cognitive: It would involve both emotions/attitudes and mental processes, which is not the primary focus in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

 

Reference: Milde FK. The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 1988;10(4):425-434.

questions.text: Which method of measurement of scoliosis has been depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cobb’s angle

 

  • This X-ray of spine shows lateral curvature (scoliosis) and angle marked is for its measurement – Cobb’s angle.

 

COBB’S ANGLE

 

  • Most widely used measurement to quantify the magnitude of spinal scoliosis, on plain radiographs.
  • Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb angle of >10°.
  • A Cobb angle can also aid kyphosis or lordosis assessment in the sagittal plane.
  • Measurement:
    • To measure the Cobb angle, one must first decide which vertebrae are the end vertebrae of the curve deformity (the terminal vertebrae) – the vertebra whose endplates are most tilted towards each other. 
    • Lines are then drawn along the endplates (or the pedicles if the endplates are not properly visualized), and the angle between the two lines, where they intersect, measured. 
    • In cases where the curvature is not marked, then the lines will not intersect on the film/monitor, in which case a further two lines can be plotted, each at right angles to the previous lines.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kite’s angle. Kite’s angle or talocalcaneal angle is the angle between the lines drawn down the axis of the talus and calcaneus measured on weight bearing foot radiograph. This angle varies depending on the position of the calcaneus under the talus and the stiffness of the foot ligaments. Measurement: midtalar line should pass through/just medial to the base of 1st metatarsal and the mid-calcaneal line should pass through the base of 4th metatarsal. In hindfoot varus, the talocalcaneal angle is < 25⁰; in hindfoot valgus, it is > 40⁰; while in a normal foot, it is 25-40⁰.

 

 

Option C. Bohler’s angle. Tuber angle of Bohler (Tuber-joint angle) is used in the assessment of intra-articular calcaneal fractures. It is formed between a line drawn from highest points of anterior process of the calcaneus and highest point of posterior facet, and a line drawn tangentially to the superior edge of the calcaneal tuberosity. It is normally 20-40 degrees. Flattening/Reduction/Reversal of this angle indicates that the weight-bearing posterior facet has collapsed (intra-articular fracture) or Degree of proximal displacement of the tuberosity (intra-articular and extra-articular fracture both).

 

 

Option D. Gissane angle. Also known as critical angle of Gissane, it is used to evaluate the severity of calcaneal fractures. It is formed by two cortical struts extending laterally, one along the lateral margin of posterior facet and other extending to the beak of the calcaneus. Normally, it is an obtuse angle of 95-105 degree. It increases in intra-articular fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows the Cobb’s angle, which is used for the measurement of degree of lateral curvature of the spine in scoliosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is diagnosed with osteosarcoma and is scheduled to undergo chemotherapy as part of his treatment. Methotrexate is included in his chemotherapy regimen. What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of his osteosarcoma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR.

 

Methotrexate has different mechanisms for anticancer activity and for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

 

Mechanism in Osteosarcoma (As anticancer drug): Methotrexate acts as a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate interferes with the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, an essential cofactor for DNA synthesis. This leads to a decrease in DNA and RNA synthesis, thereby arresting the cell cycle and inhibiting the growth of rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells in osteosarcoma.

 

Mechanism in Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA): Methotrexate is used at much lower doses in Rheumatoid Arthritis. In this condition, the major mechanism involves the inhibition of an enzyme called AICAR transformylase, part of the purine synthesis pathway. When AICAR transformylase is inhibited, levels of AICAR (5-aminoimidazole-4-carboxamide ribonucleotide) accumulate in the cell. This leads to an inhibition of another enzyme called adenosine deaminase, which is responsible for the degradation of adenosine. As a result, adenosine levels increase within the cell and in the extracellular environment. Adenosine is known to have anti-inflammatory properties. When adenosine interacts with its receptors, it can lead to various effects such as inhibition of inflammatory cell function, vasodilation, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine release. These actions contribute to the anti-inflammatory effects observed when methotrexate is used for treating RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Analog of UMP: Methotrexate is not an analog of UMP (uridine monophosphate). It does not exert its effects through this mechanism.

 

Option C. Blocks purine synthesis: Methotrexate does not specifically block purine synthesis, although the inhibition of DHFR indirectly affects purine and pyrimidine synthesis.

 

Option D. Blocks pyrimidine synthesis: Similar to Option C, methotrexate does not specifically block pyrimidine synthesis but indirectly affects it through DHFR inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate's primary mechanism of action in treating osteosarcoma is as a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which interferes with DNA synthesis and cell division in rapidly dividing cells.

questions.text: A family consumes only polished rice. Which of the following combination of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect will be present in this family? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine – Transketolase

 

This is the correct combination. Consuming polished rice can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Transketolase is an enzyme involved in thiamine-dependent reactions, and its activity can be affected by thiamine deficiency, leading to various health issues, including beriberi, which is associated with thiamine deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin - Glutathione Reductase: This combination is not relevant to the consumption of polished rice. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and glutathione reductase is not directly related to this deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine - Transaminase: While thiamine deficiency can affect various enzymes, transaminase is not specifically associated with thiamine deficiency related to polished rice consumption.

 

Option D. Riboflavin - Transketolase: This combination is not relevant to polished rice consumption. Riboflavin deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and transketolase is not directly related to riboflavin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The consumption of polished rice leads to thiamine deficiency which leads to defective transketolase activity.

 

Polished rice undergoes milling, which removes the outer bran layer rich in B vitamins and other nutrients

questions.text: During which week of embryonic development does cardiac activity typically commence? (NEET PG  2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4th week

 

By the fourth week, the early heart begins to form and starts its contractions. The heart develops from a simple linear tube into a looping structure during this time. This looping eventually gives rise to the various chambers of the heart. Towards the end of the 4th week, the heart starts to beat and pump blood. However, it's worth noting that while the heart starts to beat during this week, the full structure of the heart with its four chambers isn't fully developed yet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd week: During the second week of embryonic development, formation of the bilaminar embryonic disc takes place, which consists of the epiblast and hypoblast. Additionally, events like the formation of the amniotic cavity, yolk sac and gastrulation begins towards the end of this week. At this point, the heart has not yet begun to form, and thus, there's no heart beating during the 2nd week.

 

Option C. 6th week: By the sixth week, the heart's development has progressed further. The interatrial and interventricular septa are beginning to form. While the heart is beating and becoming more sophisticated in its function, it had already started its contractions in the 4th week.

 

Option D. 10th week: By the 10th week, the embryonic period is concluding, and the fetal period is about to commence. The heart is much more developed, with more defined chambers and valves. Most major organs and external structures are formed by this time, and the fetus looks unmistakably human.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The heart starts to beat in the 4th week of development.

questions.text: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear that he reaches out to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 months

 

Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months.

 

 

Fig: Bidextrous grasp approach to a dangling ring 4 months

 

Fine motor development:

 

  • Hands come together in midline by 5 months
  • Bidextrous Reach comes by 4 months
  • Tries to reach for object from both hand will be bidextrous approach & from one hand will be unidextrous approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bidextrous reach, where a baby uses both hands to reach out for objects, is typically achieved by 4 months of age.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a history of recurrent abortions is now diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What would be the best mode of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspirin + heparin

 

Explanation

 

Aspirin + heparin:

 

  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss, thrombosis, and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • The primary cause of pregnancy loss in APS is believed to be due to inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation, which leads to placental dysfunction.
  • The best management approach for pregnant women with APS includes:
    • Low dose aspirin: Initiated as soon as pregnancy is confirmed. Aspirin helps by preventing platelet aggregation and improving blood flow to the placenta.
    • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Started once fetal cardiac activity is detected. LMWH helps prevent blood clot formation, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin only: While low-dose aspirin is beneficial, it is not sufficient alone for the prevention of complications in APS. The addition of heparin provides better protection against thrombosis and pregnancy loss.

 

Option C. Aspirin + heparin + steroids: Steroids are not routinely used in the management of APS during pregnancy due to their potential side effects and lack of evidence showing added benefit in preventing pregnancy loss when combined with aspirin and heparin.

 

Option D. Aspirin + steroids: Similar to the previous option, steroids are not recommended as part of the standard management for APS in pregnancy. The combination of aspirin and heparin is the preferred treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Ref: Page no 2907, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Surgery where one nostril is partially or completely occluded is done for which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Complete closure of the nostrils (Young's operation) is done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.

 

Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule which are re-opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa becomes normal, and the crusting is reduced.

 

In Modified Young's operation, partial closure of the nostril is done to avoid discomfort.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasomotor rhinitis - Typically managed with medications such as antihistamines and nasal sprays; surgery is not a standard treatment.

 

Option C. Invasive aspergillosis - Treatment involves antifungal medications; surgical debridement may be necessary but does not involve closing the nostrils.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis - Managed with allergy medications, immunotherapy, and avoiding allergens; surgery is not indicated for occluding nostrils.

 

Educational Objective:
