Young's operation is a unique surgical technique reserved for severe cases of atrophic rhinitis where other treatments have failed. This procedure helps in restoring the normal function and structure of the nasal mucosa by temporarily occluding the nostrils to allow healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 173

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 4

 

  • The given image shows a pressure sore with extensive tissue destruction, including damage to the muscle layer and thus it belongs to stage 4.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Stage 1: Non-blanchable erythema of intact skin. Redness that does not fade when pressure is applied.
  • Stage 2: Partial-thickness skin loss with exposed dermis. The wound bed is viable, pink or red, and moist.
  • Stage 3: Full-thickness skin loss. Subcutaneous fat may be visible, but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed.
  • Stage 4: Full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Exposed or directly palpable fascia, muscle, tendon, ligament, cartilage, or bone in the ulcer.
  • Unstageable: Obscured full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Extent of tissue damage within the ulcer cannot be confirmed because it is obscured by slough or eschar.
  • Deep Tissue Pressure Injury: Persistent non-blanchable deep red, maroon, or purple discoloration.

 

Treatment Focus:

 

  • Patient Optimization: Addressing poor nutrition and managing ongoing medical problems.
  • Preventative Measures: Implementing strategies to prevent further pressure injuries.
  • Debridement: Removing necrotic tissue if appropriate.

 

Given the extensive tissue destruction shown in the image, with damage extending through the muscle layer, the pressure sore is classified as a Stage 4 pressure injury.

questions.text: A case of urinary bladder stone with a history of Proteus infection is likely to be? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phosphate

 

Proteus infection in the urinary tract is commonly associated with the formation of struvite stones, which are also known as triple phosphate stones. Struvite stones consist of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate. Proteus species produce the enzyme urease, which hydrolyzes urea into ammonia, increasing the urine pH and promoting the precipitation of phosphate, magnesium, and ammonium to form struvite stones.

 

These stones are often described as "infection stones" because they typically form in alkaline urine in the presence of a urinary tract infection caused by urease-producing bacteria like Proteus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxalate: Oxalate stones are primarily composed of calcium oxalate and are not directly related to infections. They are often associated with dietary factors, hyperoxaluria, or conditions causing increased oxalate excretion.

 

Option C. Uric acid: Uric acid stones form in acidic urine and are related to conditions that increase uric acid levels, such as gout or a high purine diet. They are not associated with Proteus infections or other urease-producing bacteria.

 

Option D. Cystine: Cystine stones are associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder that leads to the excessive excretion of cystine in the urine. These stones are characterized by their hexagonal crystal shape but are not related to Proteus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary bladder stones associated with Proteus infection are most likely to be struvite (triple phosphate) stones, formed due to the alkalinizing effect of urease-producing bacteria on the urine.

questions.text: Dose for a new drug is assessed in which phase of Clinical trial? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Phase 1

 

Phase 1: This phase involves testing the drug on a small number of healthy human volunteers. The primary objective is to evaluate the drug's safety profile, non-toxicity, and determine the appropriate dosage range. Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) is often calculated in this phase, which makes it crucial for dose assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phase 2: Phase 2 clinical trials are designed to assess the efficacy of a drug or treatment. These trials involve a larger group of participants (100) than Phase 1 and aim to provide preliminary data on whether the drug works in people who have a certain condition or disease. Phase 2 trials also continue to monitor the drug's safety and side effects.

 

Option C. Phase 3: Phase 3 trials are conducted on a larger scale to confirm the drug's efficacy, monitor side effects, compare it to commonly used treatments, and collect information that will allow the drug to be used safely. These trials involve a larger number of participants and provide the critical data needed for regulatory approval. Drugs launched post this phase.

 

Option D. Phase 4: Phase 4 trials occur after the drug has been approved for use by the FDA. These post-marketing studies monitor the long-term effectiveness and impact on the general population, including any rare or long-term side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a patient, the hypothalamic thermostat was reset from point V to point X as shown below. Which of the following happens in stage W compared to stage Y?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Shivering

 

Explanation:

 

In the above scenario, the patient's hypothalamic thermostat has been reset to a higher temperature, hence the body uses methods like shivering to increase the temperature.

 

 

 

Fig: Effects changing the set-point of the hypothalamic temperature

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sweating

 

  • Stage W: Sweating is unlikely in this phase because the body is in the process of heating up to meet the new higher set point. Sweating is a mechanism used to reduce body temperature and would be counterproductive at this stage.
  • Stage Y: Sweating becomes prominent here as the body seeks to dissipate excess heat after reaching or surpassing the set point.

 

Option C. Increased blood flow to the skin

 

  • Stage W: There is typically decreased blood flow to the skin during this phase due to vasoconstriction, which helps to retain heat. Increasing blood flow to the skin would be counterproductive as it would lead to increased heat loss.
  • Stage Y: Increased blood flow to the skin occurs in this phase to facilitate heat loss through the skin, aiding in thermoregulation by cooling the body down.

 

Option D. Inhibition of chemical thermogenesis

 

  • Stage W: There is actually an increase in chemical thermogenesis during this stage. Chemical thermogenesis, including actions such as the metabolic effects of shivering and brown fat activation, helps to generate additional heat.
  • Stage Y: As the body temperature stabilizes or exceeds the set point, there might be a natural reduction in chemical thermogenesis as the need to generate heat reduces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TEMPERATURE REGULATION -

questions.text: Scenario with primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characters present, uterus and ovaries present with an image as shown. What is the likely karyotype? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 46 XX

 

The scenario describes a patient with primary amenorrhea, secondary sexual characteristics, and a presence of the uterus and ovaries. The image shows an obstruction in the vaginal opening, which is likely an imperforate hymen. The presence of secondary sexual characteristics and normal internal reproductive organs, such as the uterus and ovaries, indicates that the chromosomal pattern is normal female, 46 XX. The karyotype is not affected by the physical obstruction causing the amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 45 XO: This karyotype is characteristic of Turner syndrome, where patients usually have streak ovaries, lack secondary sexual characteristics, and have other distinct features like webbed neck and short stature, none of which are present in this scenario.

 

Option C. 47 XXY: This karyotype corresponds to Klinefelter syndrome, typically found in males who present with hypogonadism, tall stature, and often gynecomastia. It is not applicable to the described scenario with a female presentation.

 

Option D. 46 XY: This karyotype is associated with male individuals or conditions like Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome. The presence of normal female internal reproductive structures (uterus and ovaries) rules out 46 XY.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with normal development of secondary sexual characteristics and intact internal female reproductive organs (uterus and ovaries) generally indicates a normal female karyotype, 46 XX.

questions.text: Tiny bleeding spots observed after the removal of deep scales in Plaque Psoriasis is known as: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auspitz Sign

 

  • Auspitz sign is a characteristic finding in psoriasis observed during a three-step process. 
  • First, lesions are gently scraped with a glass slide to accentuate the silvery scales (Grattage test). 

 

 

  • As scraping continues, a glistening white adherent membrane called Bulkley's membrane appears.
  • When this membrane is removed, punctate bleeding points become visible - this is the positive Auspitz sign. 

 

 

  • These bleeding points occur due to the dilated and tortuous capillary loops in the dermal papillae that become exposed after scale removal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hutchinson Sign:


 Hutchinson sign refers to two different entities depending on the context:

 

  1. In herpes zoster ophthalmicus, it indicates vesicular lesions on the tip of the nose, signaling nasociliary nerve involvement and a high risk of ocular complications.




     
  2. Subungual melanoma it refers to pigmentation extending onto the proximal or lateral nail folds, suggesting malignancy.

     

It has no association with tiny bleeding spots or plaque psoriasis and is not observed after removal of scales.

 

Option C. Dariers Sign:

 

  • Dariers sign is seen in mastocytosis or urticaria pigmentosa. 
  • It refers to the appearance of a wheal and erythema when a lesion is rubbed or stroked due to mast cell degranulation. 

 

 

 

Option D. Nikolsky Sign:

 

  • The Nikolsky sign is positive in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris, where acantholysis leads to intraepidermal cleavage. 

 

 

  • Rubbing normal-appearing skin causes the outer layers to slough off. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auspitz sign is the appearance of tiny bleeding spots after removal of deep scales in plaque psoriasis due to exposure of dermal capillaries.

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sickle cell anemia

 

History is suggestive of dactylitis precipitated by playing causing microvascular obstruction. Shrunken spleen suggestive of auto splenectomy with recurrent episodes of dactylitis suggests sickle cell anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria: Typically presents with cyclical fever, chills, and splenomegaly rather than a shrunken spleen. The history of recurrent hand swelling isn't typical for malaria.

 

Option C. Pancreatitis: Main symptoms include severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, unrelated to the symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Measles: Characterized by a rash, fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots, none of which relate to the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

In a child presenting with fever and recurrent hand swelling following physical activity, alongside a history of a shrunken spleen, sickle cell anemia should be considered a primary diagnosis. This highlights the importance of considering hemoglobinopathies in patients with peculiar skeletal pains and organ findings suggestive of chronic hemolytic processes.

 

Reference - Harrison 21 /Hemoglobinopathies/Chapter 98

choices.text: Retinal pigmentation
Pale waxy disc
Narrowing of vessels
ERG – normal

questions.text: What among the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. ERG – normal

 

ERG is abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa.

 

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a primary pigmentary retinal dystrophy predominantly affecting the rods more than the cones.
  • It is the most common hereditary fundus dystrophy, with the most common mode of inheritance being autosomal recessive.
  • In early disease, it shows reduced scotopic rod and combined responses, and photopic responses reduce with progression.
  • Eventually, the ERG becomes extinguished.
  • The characteristic visual symptom is night blindness, which may present several years before visible changes in the retina appear.
  • Dark adaptation is affected, and tubular vision may occur in advanced cases.
  • Fundus changes include bone-spicule retinal pigmentation, arteriolar attenuation, and 'waxy' disc pallor.

 

  • Visual field changes-
    • Annular or ring-shaped scotoma is a typical feature which corresponds to the degenerated equatorial zone of retina. As the disease progresses, scotoma increases anteriorly and posteriorly and ultimately only central vision is left (tubular vision). Eventually even this is also lost and the patient becomes blind.

 

  • Electrophysiological changes-

1. Electro-retinogram (ERG) is subnormal or abolished.

2. Electro-oculogram (EOG) shows absence of light peak.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Pale Waxy Disc: Optic disc pallor due to progressive degeneration.

 

Option C. Narrowing of Vessels: Attenuation of retinal arterioles due to retinal thinning and atrophy.

 

Option D.  ERG (Electroretinogram: ERG is not normal in retinitis pigmentosa. It shows abnormal findings, such as:

  • Early Disease: Reduced scotopic (rod) response and combined responses.
  • Progression: Reduced photopic (cone) responses.
  • Advanced Disease: ERG becomes extinguished or abolished

 

Educational Objective:

 

In retinitis pigmentosa, the ERG is not normal; it shows progressive abnormalities reflecting the degeneration of photoreceptor cells. Other features include retinal pigmentation, pale waxy disc, and narrowing of retinal vessels.
